{{short description|Ancient Egyptian symbol of protection, royal power and good health}} {{About|the ancient Egyptian symbol|the video game|Eye of Horus (video game)}} {{pp|small=yes}} [[File:Eye_of_Horus_Right.svg|thumb|right|The Eye of Horus]] [[File:Wedjat (Udjat) Eye of Horus pendant.jpg|thumb|right|An Eye of Horus or Wedjat [[pendant]]]]
The '''Eye of Horus''', also known as '''wadjet''', '''wedjat'''<ref>{{cite book|last=Pommerening |first=Tanja |title=Die altÃ¤gyptischen HohlmaÃŸe |series=Studien zur AltÃ¤gyptischen Kultur |volume=Beiheft 10 |location=Hamburg |publisher=Helmut Buske Verlag |year=2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Art History |volume=Volume 1 |first=Marilyn |last=Stokstad |chapter=Chapter 3: Art of Ancient Egypt |publisher=Pearson Prentice Hall |location=Upper Saddle River, N.J. |year=2007 |edition=3rd |isbn=9780131743205 |oclc=238783244}}</ref><ref name=Silverman>{{cite book |authorlink=David P. Silverman |last=Silverman |first=David P. |chapter=Chapter 14: Egyptian Art |title=Ancient Egypt |publisher=Duncan Baird Publishers |year=1997 |page=228}}</ref> or '''udjat''',<ref>{{cite book |editor1-first=Alessandro |editor1-last=Bongioanni |editor2-first=Maria |editor2-last=Croce |title=The Treasures of Ancient Egypt: From the Egyptian Museum in Cairo |publisher=Universe Publishing |year=2003 |page=622}} According to the editors, "Udjat" was the term for amulets which used the Eye of Horus design.</ref><ref name="Henadology">{{cite web |url=http://henadology.wordpress.com/theology/netjeru/wadjet |title=Wadjet |last=Butler |first=Edward P. |website=Goddesses and Gods of the Ancient Egyptians: A Theological Encyclopedia |publisher=Henadology: Philosophy and Theology |accessdate=October 4, 2010 }}</ref> is an [[ancient Egypt]]ian symbol of protection, royal power, and good health. The Eye of Horus is similar to the [[Eye of Ra]], which belongs to a different god, [[Ra]], but represents many of the same concepts.
Funerary amulets were often made in the shape of the Eye of Horus.<ref name=Silverman/> The symbol "was intended to protect the pharaoh [here] in the afterlife"<ref name=Silverman/> and to ward off evil. Ancient Egyptian and Middle-Eastern sailors would frequently [[Apotropaic magic|paint the symbol on the bows of their vessels]] to ensure safe sea travel.<ref>{{cite book |first=Charles |last=Freeman |title=The Legacy of Ancient Egypt |publisher=Facts on File |year=1997 |page=91}}</ref>
==Horus== [[Horus]] was the [[Ancient Egyptian religion|ancient Egyptian]] sky god who was usually depicted as a [[falcon]], most likely a [[Lanner falcon|lanner]] or [[peregrine falcon]].<ref>Wilkinson, Richard H. (2003). ''The Complete Gods and Goddesses of Ancient Egypt''. Thames & Hudson. p. 202.</ref> His right eye was associated with the sun god, [[Ra]]. The eye symbol represents the marking around the eye of the falcon, including the "[[Tears|teardrop]]" marking sometimes found below the eye. The mirror image, or left eye, sometimes represented the [[moon]] and the god Djehuti ([[Thoth]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://symboldictionary.net/?p=519 |title=Eye of Horus, Eye of Ra (Udjat, Wedjet) |publisher=Symboldictionary.net |date= |accessdate=2012-01-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223170538/http://symboldictionary.net/?p=519 |archive-date=2012-02-23 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
{{Hiero|wedjet â€“ Eye of Horus|<hiero>D10</hiero>|align=right|era=egypt}} It was believed by the Greeks and Romans that an evil heart could get to the eye. The thought to be powerful effects of eyes and optics created the myth that the energy-producing power of the eye had the ability to cast evil spells with just a glance. Because the ancients believed the evil eye could be counteracted with a 'good eye', myths about Horus arose.<ref>Bohigian, G. (1997). The history of the evil eye and its influence on ophthalmology, medicine and social customs. Documenta Ophthalmologica, 94(1), 91-100.</ref>
In one myth, when [[Set (mythology)|Set]] and [[Horus]] were fighting for the throne after [[Osiris]]'s death, Set gouged out Horus's left eye. The majority of the eye was restored by either [[Hathor]] or Thoth. When Horus's eye was recovered, he offered it to his father, [[Osiris]], in hopes of restoring his life. Hence, the eye of Horus was often used to symbolise sacrifice, healing, restoration, and protection.<ref>Pinch, Geraldine (2004). ''Egyptian Mythology: A Guide to the Gods, Goddesses, and Traditions of Ancient Egypt''. Oxford University Press. pp. 131â€“132</ref>
==As hieroglyph and symbol== There are seven different [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|hieroglyph]]s used to represent the eye, most commonly "ir.t" in Egyptian, which also has the meaning "to make or do" or "one who does".<ref name="Henadology" /> In Egyptian myth the eye was not the passive organ of sight but more an agent of action, protection or wrath. The Eye of Horus was represented as a hieroglyph, designated [[List of hieroglyphs/D#D10|D10]] in [[Gardiner's sign list]].<ref>Allen, James P. (2000). ''Middle Egyptian: An Introduction to the Language and Culture of Hieroglyphs''. Cambridge University Press. p. 426</ref> It is represented in the [[Unicode]] character block for Egyptian hieroglyphs as U+13080 (ð“‚€).<ref>[https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U13000.pdf Unicode standard for Egyptian hieroglyphs]</ref>
==Mathematics== [[File:Oudjat.SVG|thumb|right|Arithmetic values represented by parts of the Eye of Horus]] {{further|Egyptian fraction|1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 + ...}}
In Ancient Egypt, most fractions were written as the sum of two or more [[unit fraction]]s (a fraction with 1 as the numerator), with scribes possessing tables of answers (see [[Rhind Mathematical Papyrus 2/n table]]).<ref>Zaslavsky, Claudia (1993). ''Multicultural Mathematics: Interdisciplinary Cooperative-Learning Activities'', p. 20. {{ISBN|9780825121814}}.</ref> Thus instead of {{frac|3|4}}, one would write {{frac|1|2}} + {{frac|1|4}}.
Different parts of the Eye of Horus were thought to be used by the ancient Egyptians to represent one divided by the first six powers of two:<ref>{{cite book | title=Professor Stewart's Hoard of Mathematical Treasures | last=Stewart | first=Ian | publisher=Profile Books | isbn=978 1 84668 292 6 | year= 2009 | pages=76â€“80 }}</ref>
{{block indent|1=The right side of the eye = {{frac|1|2}}}} {{block indent|1=The pupil = {{frac|1|4}}}} {{block indent|1=The eyebrow = {{frac|1|8}}}} {{block indent|1=The left side of the eye = {{frac|1|16}}}} {{block indent|1=The curved tail = {{frac|1|32}}}} {{block indent|1=The teardrop = {{frac|1|64}}}}
The [[Rhind Mathematical Papyrus]] contains tables of "Horus Eye Fractions".<ref>{{cite book |author=Hilary Wilson |title=Understanding Hieroglyphs: A Complete Introductory Guide |publisher=Michael O'mara Books Ltd. |location=London |year=1995}} p. 165</ref>
Studies from the 1970s to this day in Egyptian mathematics have clearly shown this theory was fallacious and Jim Ritter definitely showed it to be false in 2003.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ritter |first=Jim |year=2002 |chapter=Closing the Eye of Horus: the Rise and Fall of 'Horus-Eye Fractions' |title=Under One Sky: Astronomy and Mathematics in the ancient Near East |editor1-first=J. |editor1-last=Steele |editor2-first=A. |editor2-last=Imhausen|editor2-link=Annette Imhausen |location=MÃ¼nster |publisher=Ugarit-Verlag |pages=297â€“323}} See also {{cite book |editor-first=V. |editor-last=Katz |year=2007 |title=The Mathematics of Egypt, Mesopotamia, China, India, and Islam: A Sourcebook |location=Princeton |publisher=Princeton University Press |postscript=,}} and {{cite book |editor1-first=E. |editor1-last=Robson |editor2-first=J. |editor2-last=Stedall |year=2009 |title=The Oxford Handbook of the History of Mathematics |location=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> The evolution of the symbols used in mathematics, although similar to the different parts of the Eye of Horus, is now known to be distinct.
